column4: *sighs* I've got a bit of a nasty problem on bootup, it's probably related to one of the options I picked when I recompiled the kernel. Can anyone help me for a couple moments with it?
*laughs* I would if I could. It's repeating series of error messages on the boot, but I don't know enough to find the bootlog afterwards, so I can't give the exact message

Yah. First time you guys told it to me, it barfed my connection, but I hardcoded a hack into the kernel, and now my internet connection is rock solid. (Though you don't even want to see what I did to that code. *shudder*) I find the concept of pastebin... curious, and I'm really surprised that you can get most people to use it. Makes sense, though
True. Didn't see the script, Dooglus, going to take another look now.
Mustard5, Well, two lines. But there are related lines before it as well, I think.
Mustard5, Ah, well, thanks anyway. Any chance you could remind me where to find the bootlog, anyway? Useful thing, that.
The last three days have really pushed my limits. Really hard to remember every little place where Linux keeps stuff.
locate is helpful to find files
well, I'm really not sure what to look for. Is it really just called 'bootlog', or something silly like that?
not sure what you are looking for, but "locate filename" is useful to find filename
Quite possibly. I was checking in there, but I can look again. It's quite easy to miss things, I think
Basically, I'm just looking for a record of the text that scrolls across my screen when I boot
seems I have a bootlog daemon installed, but not enabled by default.
need to edit /etc/default/bootlogd to enable it on boot.
*finds a log buried deep in a subdirectory* Wait a minute, this might be better.........
and looking in /etc/init.d/bootlogd startup script it would seem that /var/log/boot is where it goes.
Marcn- Ok, cool, that's certainly useful to know
/etc/init.d/ is where startup scripts are, /etc/default/ are frequently configuration files for them.  /var/log/ is where things are logged.
